text: Right now, all the SOAP libraries available for python suck.
I recommend avoiding SOAP if possible.
The last time we where forced to use a SOAP web service from python, we wrote a wrapper in C# that handled the SOAP on one side and spoke COM out the other.
I would recommend that you have a look at SUDS
"Suds is a lightweight SOAP python client for consuming Web Services.
I always write my own at the HTTP level.
I wrote the example here which should be a good starting point for you.
Let me know if you have questions.
I know this is an old thread but it was showing up at the top of google results so I wanted to share a more current discussion on Python and SOAP.
If you're rolling your own I'd highly recommend looking at http://effbot.org/zone/element-soap.htm.
It's not true SOAPpy does not work with Python 2.5 - it works, although it's very simple and really, really basic.
If you want to talk to any more complicated webservice, ZSI is your only friend.
The really useful demo I found is at http://www.ebi.ac.uk/Tools/webservices/tutorials/python - this really helped me to understand how ZSI works.
SOAPpy is now obsolete, AFAIK, replaces by ZSL.
It's a moot point, because I can't get either one to work, much less compile, on either Python 2.5 or Python 2.6
